messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 48 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: LayoutGMN: Neural Graph Matching for Structural Layout Similarity

Paper Abstract: Abstract We present a deep neural network to predict structural similarity between 2D layouts by leveraging Graph Matching Networks (GMN). Our network, coined LayoutGMN, learns the layout metric via neural graph matching, using an attention-based GMN designed under a triplet network setting. To train our network, we utilize weak labels obtained by pixel-wise Intersection-over-Union (IoUs) to define the triplet loss. Importantly, LayoutGMN is built with a structural bias which can effectively compensate for the lack of structure awareness in IoUs. We demonstrate this on two prominent forms of layouts, viz., floorplans and UI designs, via retrieval experiments on large-scale datasets. In particular, retrieval results by our network better match human judgement of structural layout similarity compared to both IoUs and other baselines including a state-of-the-art method based on graph neural networks and image convolution. In addition, LayoutGMN is the first deep model to offer both metric learning of structural layout similarity and structural matching between layout elements.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 48 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 48"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Specifying object attributes and relations in interactive scene generation",
        "Inter-annotator agreement for a german newspaper corpus",
        "High performance document layout analysis",
        "Geometric deep learning: going beyond euclidean data",
        "Intelligent home 3d: Automatic 3d-house design from linguistic descriptions only",
        "GRIDS: Interactive layout design with integer programming",
        "Rico: A mobile app dataset for building data-driven design applications",
        "Characterizing structural relationships in scenes using graph kernels",
        "Towards a methodology for named entities annotation",
        "3D-FRONT: 3D Furnished Rooms with layOuts and semaNTics",
        "READ: Recursive autoencoders for document layout generation",
        "Aligning linguistic words and visual semantic units for image captioning",
        "Deep metric learning using triplet network",
        "Reference standards, judges, and comparison subjects: roles for experts in evaluating system performance",
        "Graph2Plan: Learning floorplan generation from layout graphs",
        "Review of automatic document formatting",
        "Image generation from scene graphs",
        "Document image analysis, volume 39",
        "Graph convolutional network for multi-label vhr remote sensing scene recognition",
        "Corpus annotation for mining biomedical events from literature",
        "Semi-supervised classification with graph convolutional networks",
        "SHED: shape edit distance for fine-grained shape similarity",
        "Bricolage: example-based retargeting for web design",
        "Batch decorrelation for active metric learning",
        "LayoutGAN: Generating graphic layouts with wireframe discriminator",
        "GRAINS: Generative recursive autoencoders for indoor scenes",
        "Graph matching networks for learning the similarity of graph structured objects",
        "Gated graph sequence neural networks",
        "Learning design semantics for mobile apps",
        "Learning structural similarity of user interface layouts using graph networks",
        "Chapter 8: Evaluation in information retrieval in “Introduction to Information Retrieval”",
        "House-gan: Relational generative adversarial networks for graph-constrained house layout generation",
        "Learning layouts for single-page graphic designs",
        "d. tour: Style-based exploration of design example galleries",
        "U-net: Convolutional networks for biomedical image segmentation",
        "Modeling relational data with graph convolutional networks",
        "Rewire: Interface design assistance from examples",
        "Automatic layout generation for graphical design magazines",
        "Compact scene graphs for layout composition and patch retrieval",
        "The room connectivity graph: Shape retrieval in the architectural domain",
        "New directions in biomedical text annotation: definitions, guidelines and corpus construction",
        "Data-driven interior plan generation for residential buildings",
        "Organizing heterogeneous scene collections through contextual focal points",
        "Exploring visual relationship for image captioning",
        "A methodology towards effective and efficient manual document annotation: addressing annotator discrepancy and annotation quality",
        "Structured3D: A Large Photo-realistic Dataset for Structured 3D Modeling",
        "Content-aware generative modeling of graphic design layouts",
        "Publaynet: largest dataset ever for document layout analysis"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 48 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in LayoutGMN: Neural Graph Matching for Structural Layout Similarity, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
